What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Lots of different ways to formalize the current world of Machine Learning and Data Science. PAC Learning, VC Dimension, Clustering, etc.

We studied some of the foundational theoretical ideas behind Machine Learning and Data Science. Many of these concepts followed Shalev-Shwartz and Ben-David's text, "Understanding Machine Learning". Some specific ideas we covered were Graph Laplacians, PAC learning, VC dimension (computed for several concrete examples of hypothesis classes), The No-Free-Lunch Theorem, Cybenko's Theorem, and Neural Networks.
PAC learning, VC dimension, support vector machines, gradient descent, dimension reduction, neural nets

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course - one of the few seminar feeling classes I've taken in the department. Lectures felt like there was a clear progression of ideas, and even when we were bogged down in long proofs, it was clear what the important points were.

One major strength of the course was the final presentation format. This was a conference-style series of presentations on data-science-related topics. It was both an interesting experience and, personally, aligned with my preferred learning style.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student - particularly if they are interested in increasing their familiarity with research-level thinking in a related field.
Yes for people interested in the topics covered in the course! Professor Gilbert is wonderful.
